title: Monday, 25th February 2019
bodyHTML:
VV75 morning
Blank canvas Good morning all
11:04 am
BE11:04am

And again. Good morning. Welcome. Hello.

Soundbuy Morning
VV75 gold merger just now on tape
BE11:05am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

BE11:05am

And we have Barrick-Newmont crossing the tape.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

BARRICK MAKES PROPOSAL TO BUY NEWMONT IN ALL-STOCK DEAL

BE11:05am

BARRICK HOLDERS WOULD OWN ABOUT 55.9% OF MERGED CO WITH NEWMONT

DJ morning
BE11:06am

BARRICK, NEWMONT DEAL EXCHANGE RATIO OF 2.5694 BARRICK SHARES

11:06 am
BE11:06am

That should make today's BMO gold conference more interesting than usual

Upaswellasdown and a lovely sunny morning it is too
wayneJ Hi Upaswellasdown - free to discuss TSCO?
BornCynic Morning
red is this another nil premium where only the banks handling are guaranteed anything out of it
BE11:07am

Newmont's CEO's due to make an appearance, though that may need a very quick rethink.

BE11:08am

(@wayneJ, @Upaswellasdown: by all means talk Tesco, though maybe here's not the ideal place for a one-on-one chat?)

Montesquieu John Thornton won't take no for an answer. Not sure really how close they got in 2014. But Goldberg's reaction was widely anticipated, so there is stamina aplenty.
Forester Centamin? - 20%
wayneJ (@BE - sorry BE - it was a hanging item from last week - bear with us? Is based on a FTAV article)
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Whichever way, it's an amazingly aggressive bit of deal engineering.

BornCynic Centamin please BE? Whilst you are on gold miners...........
BE11:10am

Let me throw in some grey, obviously stale now but still useful.

BE11:10am

JPMorgan.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

The logic for this proposal is that it would unlock synergies from consolidating Barrick's and Newmont's large mining footprints in Nevada and probably Colorado.

BE11:11am

We estimate this opportunity could be worth at least US$3bn. We feel it’s unlikely that Newmont shareholders would be willing to share this equally with Barrick when it is likely close to concluding its own accretive deal with Goldcorp. Media speculation also mentioned that Newcrest may have a role to play as an acquirer of non-core Australian assets. We think NCM's balance sheet could comfortably absorb US$4bn in cash-based acquisitions; going above this level may require equity

wayneJ The main issue re Tesco I found is the one Upaswell highlighted - why a 7% discount rate; especially as SBRY on around 5.5% for lease liabilities.
BE11:12am

Audacious rather than impossible is the term we’d
use for the idea that, just after incoming CEO Mark Bristow officially begins the task of optimizing the Barrick assets, the company would look at a big new deal. Generally, a company in Barrick’s position would be considered to be out of the market. Yet we have to consider where new management can create value in Barrick. When Barrick was talking with Newmont about a deal in 2014 we recall the total synergies discussed were ~US$800m a year, of which perhaps US$500m were to be sourced from Nevada. Four years of cost cutting have likely reduced these to perhaps a conservative US$250-350m/year, but over 10 years this is still the equivalent of the full value of one of Newmont’s best mines like Tanami & we wouldn’t be surprised at claims that the synergies could be significantly higher.

VV75 any read through on Barrick's London listed daughter Acacia?
Upaswellasdown (@ WayneJ - drop me an email at upaswell@mailinator.com)
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Barrick bought Placer Dome in 2005. Initially the Placer deal was hostile but eventually terms were agreed. Hostile deals are rare in the gold sector but in the case of Placer the attraction of the company, which gave Barrick two of its tier one assets Cortez and Pueblo Viejo, was too great. Of course many of the synergies of unitizing Nevada could be achieved simply by creating a JV. It’s possible that even without a full bid for Newmont there’s a new impetus for unifying Nevada that would benefit both sets of shareholders.

wayneJ Second issue is that TSCO on a quick glance appears to have 1.49x the sales in the UK of Sainsbury but only 84% of the PPE which seemed odd.
wayneJ @Ups - will do
BE11:14am

And RBC.

BE11:14am

Our Barrick-Newmont merger scenario analysis based on our models at $1,300/oz gold indicates that
on a per-share basis, an at-the-market merger would be 21% accretive to Barrick shareholders on 3-year
attributable free cash flow (FCF), relatively neutral to EBITDA and operating cash flow (OCF), and 5%
dilutive on an NAV basis (Exhibit 1). As such, the same scenario would be accretive to NEM shareholders
on the basis of NAV (+21%), 3-year EBITDA and OCF (+13% and +9%) while 2% dilutive to near-term
FCF per share.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

undefined
BE11:15am

And at the other end of the pile, there's Centamin.

11:15 am
Centamin PLC (CEY:LSE): Last: 109.10, down 25.25 (-18.79%), High: 133.70, Low: 104.40, Volume: 12.60m
wayneJ (Third issue - and then I will stop - the Morrissons disclosures are interesting as they give more detail on fuel sales, volume-based rebates, marketing & advertising funding - indeed one could argue that those items plus freehold property are the real core of supermarket profitability.)
BE11:15am

Results are okay. Production guidance isn't.

Nestor Makhno deal integration risk with Barick/Newmont/Randgold must be pretty elevated
BE11:16am

2019 guidance at the bottom of the range suggests no improvement from 2018.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

And given 2018 was meant to be an exceptionally bad year, this is being read as very negative.

BE11:17am

Management was already in the doghouse. This hasn't helped at all.

BE11:17am

There was also a bit of hope in the price that there might've been a better final dividend .....

11:18 am
BE11:18am

.. but weak production + fixed costs = the obvious so they're playing cautious.

BE11:18am

Numbers summarised by Goldman:

BE11:18am

Key points
Revenues: The company reported revenue of US$603mn vs. consensus
n(Starmine) estimates of US$599.4mn. This was also in line with our estimate of US$604mn.
EBITDA - came in at US$258mn, in line with consensus estimate of US$258mn.
nIt was c. 4% below our estimate of US$270mn on higher costs.
Dividend: The company announced a dividend USc3/share - which takes the final
ndividend to USc5.5/shr. This is in line with consensus estimates but below our estimates of USc6.5/shr.
Guidance: 1) 2019 production guidance is c. 490-520Koz. 2) Cash cost of
nproduction in 2019 is expected to be between US$675-US$725 per ounce produced and AISC between US$890-US$950 per ounce sold. 3) Capital expenditure of US$118 million, of which US$89.2 million is sustaining capital investment, including ongoing underground development and phased fleet rebuild programme. 4) Exploration budget is US$40mn.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And RBC with a bit more detail.

BE11:19am

Overall CEY’s FY18 results were -4% weaker than (last available) company consensus and -3% below our estimates at EBITDA. We thought CEY
had the potential to pay out a final dividend above policy given the group’s strong cash balance (FY18: $322 mn) and disappointing operational performance in
2018. Instead US3.0c/sh was in line with policy, taking the FY pay-out to US5.5c/sh -29% below our forecast and broadly in line with consensus. Looking
beyond the results, it is the FY19 outlook that we think is more negative today. Volume guidance of 490-520koz is in line with our 514koz forecast but below
(last available) consensus of 560koz. We think that as a minimum the Street would have been expecting a return to levels similar to or in line with FY17’s actual
production of 545koz and would also note that initial FY18 guidance was 580koz.
On top of the lower volumes produced stripping appears to have increased materially in 2019 to include material movement for Stage 5 of the open pit. This, and
we assume some deferred sustaining capital from 2018, drives All-in Sustaining Cost (AISC) guidance to US$890-950/oz higher than our $886/oz forecast and
(last available) consensus of $809/oz. This would suggest lower cashflow and dividends especially as capex for a proposed solar farm and new Tailings Storage
Facility (TSF) remain subject to board approval and are not included in this guidance. Given the operational issues in 2018, it is also potentially concerning that
Mark Morcombe, CEY’s COO, has apparently left the group to join Endeavour Mining, according to a press release from Endeavour last week. The one bright
spot we can see in today’s release is on underground reserves where grades have risen +10% YoY to 5.6g/t on broadly flat ounces. Changes in cut-off grades
with the open pit make it more difficult to reconcile on a like-for-like basis. On second decline Cleopatra at the Sukari mine development will continue but there
is little “new” in terms of commitment to targets for first ounces. We expect more colour on this morning’s call.
We continue to rate CEY Sector Perform. We see potential downgrades flowing through from this morning’s FY19 outlook, particularly on the cost front. We
also think three downgrades to production guidance in 2018 have negatively impacted the group’s credibility with investors and that this will take a number of
quarters to reverse.

PBateman Nice Purp bounce
undefined
wayneJ I know BE does not tolerate swearing but anyone want to guess what 'software development costs' at cost were for Morrisons on 1st Feb 2016 on the balance sheet?
BornCynic 15.2.2019 they updated their reserves info - any grey on that please BE?

Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,333, down 135 (-5.47%), High: 2,358, Low: 2,262, Volume: 1.15m

https://www.thetim...contract-nlrq02q7h

BE11:26am

“James [Brokenshire] has become increasingly concerned by the behaviour of Persimmon in the last 12 months,” the source said. “Leasehold, build quality, their leadership seemingly not getting [that] they’re accountable to their customers are all points that have been raised by the secretary of state privately.

“Given that contracts for the 2021 extension to Help to Buy are being reviewed shortly it would be surprising if Persimmon’s approach wasn’t a point of discussion.”

red persy had a good run last couple of months. brexit extension talk not helping sector either
PBateman Bunzl if we have time later, please!
wayneJ (Trying to get current) - also worth talking about Asda / KKR?
Upaswellasdown WayneJ (ideally the second of your options. Can you send more contact details?)
11:27 am
BE11:27am

I think the journalist on lead byline, Louisa Clarence-Smith, used to be editor of Estates Gazette if you want a bit of a guess about the sourcing here.

BE11:28am

Anyway, here's Cazenove to say "not going to happen, chill".

lonrho Is there any broker comment on Reach results.
BE11:28am

Our initial assumption is that it would be difficult to
justify this move given that Persimmon doesn’t appear to have broken any specific rules, other housebuilders
have similar issues and arguably bigger individual issues at other housebuilders in recent years, such as Bovis’
2016/17 issues, went completely unpunished. We also assume that it will be relatively easy for Persimmon to
demonstrate progress being made on service and, based on the current trajectory, the group’s customer service
metrics should be closer to sector average by the time the Help to Buy renewal comes around in 2021. All this
said, we still expect the associated risk to meaningfully impact the stock today.

Upaswellasdown Do the Qataris still hold big chunk of Sainsbury's? A long time ago, they wanted to do an opco / propco
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Persimmon's only slightly worse than the average on customer service, with three stars rather than four, Caz says.

BE11:30am

But has been working towards the 80% "would recommend to a friend" level that's apparently important here.

A. M. (morning all)
BE11:31am

Also sees no evidence of big repair work required, because big repair work's expensive so shows up pretty easily on the books.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

With regards the profiteering stuff .....

BE11:31am

Persimmon is the UK’s most profitable housebuilder. It was also focused on selling relatively affordable homes to first-time buyers prior to the existence of Help to Buy.
Clearly the inception of Help to Buy only led the group to increase that focus, buying land and building
houses that serviced demand in this market. However, margins are high because land buying has clearly been
well executed and the group has driven a high level of efficiency through the build process. Help to Buy
constitutes around 48% of total Persimmon sales, vs. 36% at Barratt Developments and 43% at Taylor
Wimpey.

BE11:32am

So ........ to recap, there are lots of reasons to hate Help To Buy but not too many reasons to single out Persimmon as the biggest abuser of a hopelessly designed subsidy scheme.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Hate the game, not the player.

undefined
wayneJ Qatar - 21.87%. Looking at the numbers I would suggest that if supermarkets were doing opco / propco with RPI linked rents it would significantly impact their profits.
wayneJ (Ie impact of 50% plus in some cases)
BE11:33am

Elsewhere, there's a non-denial of the Telegraph's Laura Ashley story.

red psn 2150-2200 worth picking up imo

THE troubled British fashion icon Laura Ashley faces a shock takeover bid from a Manchester-born entrepreneur, The Sunday Telegraph can reveal. Michael Flacks, who left school at 15 to start his own retail business before making his fortune in property, is to approach Laura Ashley's Malaysian controlling shareholders in the hope of taking it private and reviving it.

"faces" ....

wayneJ It seemed from the Sunday Times article that the key asset KKR has is Asda ex boss Tony De Nunzio. If Walmart really wanted him surely they would just phone him up? And I suspect cost of capital for WMT is lower than from KKR

https://www.invest...1902250700079753Q/

Andrew Khoo, Chairman of Laura Ashley, said: "As far as I am concerned, there is no takeover bid because there has been no approach whatsoever."

Anyway, always difficult to know how to write stories when you're of the understanding that an offer has been worked on but no approach has been made.

VV75 so as long as he does not pick up the phone he will be right

https://www.ft.com...-b72b-2c7f526ca5d0

Ghazali read the BRK letter this weekend. I personally find it amusing that there was very little discussion of the KHC writedown beyond stating the numbers, but a (some) discussion about growth capex investment in 100% owned companies.
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Oil and gas group RockRose is to buy Marathon Oil subsidiaries in a reverse takeover in the latest instance of a US company withdrawing from the North Sea and being replaced by an independent operator.

RockRose has agreed to pay Marathon Oil $140m and its shares will be suspended until the deal prospectus is published.

While the sale of the Marathon assets is one of the smaller deals anticipated in the region in 2019, it is among the first since the international oil benchmark Brent crude slumped more than 30 per cent in the fourth quarter. As the UK North Sea matures and its cost base appears high compared with other regions, its place on the list of investment priorities at some oil and gas groups is slipping away.

A. M. @Soundbuy: who bought them, exactly? I couldn't tell from the NR.
BE11:47am

Assets include 37%-40% operated interests in the Greater Brae Area and 28% in the BP operated Foinaven Field unit and 47% in Foinaven East.

A. M. Should've waited for BE...

11:48 am

BE11:49am

News that the Company is acquiring Marathon's UK business is a coup for the Company, as it places the Company on a clear pathway to being significant player in the UK oil and gas segment.

Given that the management is a track record of completing the right deals at the right time and for the right price, we believe that the underlying valuation remains out of step with the wider UK and international market, even accounting for liabilities.

BE11:58am
